dictionary.definition: able to breathe clean, fresh air with no restriction or obstruction. After I got out of the dank basement, I was able to breathe easily again.
able to breathe clean, fresh air with no restriction or obstruction. After I got out of the dank basement, I was able to breathe easily again.
able to do something very easily, possibly without even looking.  Bill boasted that he could pass his driver’s test blindfolded.

dictionary.phrase: able to do something standing on one’s head
dictionary.definition: able to do something very easily, possibly without even looking.  Bill boasted that he could pass his driver’s test blindfolded.

dictionary.phrase: able to take just so much
dictionary.definition: able to endure only a limited amount of discomfort or unpleasantness.  Please stop hurting my feelings. I’m able to take just so much.

dictionary.phrase: able to take only so much
dictionary.definition: able to endure only a limited amount of discomfort or unpleasantness.  Please stop hurting my feelings. I’m able to take just so much.
Rur. beyond one’s ability.  Fixing those new cars with computers in them is above my bend.  Joe’s a good cook, but fancy desserts are above his huckleberry.
Rur. beyond one’s ability.  Fixing those new cars with computers in them is above my bend.  Joe’s a good cook, but fancy desserts are above his huckleberry.
to prove that an accused person is innocent of something; to demonstrate that someone is not responsible for something. Bob attempted to absolve himself of the crime.
to prove that an accused person is innocent of something; to demonstrate that someone is not responsible for something. Bob attempted to absolve himself of the crime.

Euph. casualties or destruction inflicted by an enemy that is considered minor or tolerable. At present, the enemy’s firststrike capability would produce acceptable damage.  The general indicated that the fifty thousand casualties were within the range of acceptable losses.

Euph. casualties or destruction inflicted by an enemy that is considered minor or tolerable. At present, the enemy’s firststrike capability would produce acceptable damage.  The general indicated that the fifty thousand casualties were within the range of acceptable losses.

dictionary.phrase: acclimate someone or an animal to something
dictionary.definition: to cause a person or other living thing to become used to a different climate or environment.  We will help acclimate Henry to the new building.  We need to acclimatize the fish to the new aquarium.

dictionary.phrase: acclimatize someone or an animal to something
dictionary.definition: to cause a person or other living thing to become used to a different climate or environment.  We will help acclimate Henry to the new building.  We need to acclimatize the fish to the new aquarium.

from all the reports [that are available]; according to what everyone is saying.  According to all accounts, the police were on the scene immediately.  By all accounts, it was a very poor performance.

from all the reports [that are available]; according to what everyone is saying.  According to all accounts, the police were on the scene immediately.  By all accounts, it was a very poor performance.
used to someone or something; used to or in the habit of doing something. (*Typically: be ~; become ~; grow ~.) _ The children are accustomed to eating late in the evening.
used to someone or something; used to or in the habit of doing something. (*Typically: be ~; become ~; grow ~.) _ The children are accustomed to eating late in the evening.
something important held in reserve. The twenty-dollar bill I keep in my shoe is my ace in the hole.
something important held in reserve. The twenty-dollar bill I keep in my shoe is my ace in the hole.
to desire someone or something very much. (So much that it “hurts.”) _ Jim ached for the sight of Mary, whom he loved deeply.
to desire someone or something very much. (So much that it “hurts.”) _ Jim ached for the sight of Mary, whom he loved deeply.

to make a problem worse; to say or do something that makes a bad situation worse; to make an angry person get even angrier. (Alludes to causing a flame to grow larger when fuel is added.) _Shouting at a crying child just adds fuel to the fire.

to make a problem worse; to say or do something that makes a bad situation worse; to make an angry person get even angrier. (Alludes to causing a flame to grow larger when fuel is added.) _Shouting at a crying child just adds fuel to the fire.
to introduce something into something else. Now, add the eggs into the mixture.  Add in some more eggs.
to introduce something into something else. Now, add the eggs into the mixture.  Add in some more eggs.

to extend something by providing more (of something). (This use of on with add is colloquial.) _You added nearly one thousand dollars onto the total. You added on a thousand dollars to the total! _ You added too much on.

a position superior to that of someone else; a status wherein one controls or has superiority or authority over someone else. (*Typically: get ~; give someone ~; have ~.) _She’d gotten an advantage over me at the start of the competition.  I got an edge on Sally, too, and she came in second.

dictionary.phrase: affiliate (someone or something) to someone or something
dictionary.definition: to cause a person or thing to be associated with some other person or thing.  He did not want to affiliate his club to the other clubs.  We tried to affiliate John with other people who shared his interests.

dictionary.phrase: affiliate (someone or something) with someone or something
dictionary.definition: to cause a person or thing to be associated with some other person or thing.  He did not want to affiliate his club to the other clubs.  We tried to affiliate John with other people who shared his interests.

dictionary.phrase: After a storm comes a calm.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Things are often calm after an upheaval.  Jill: I can’t believe how peaceful the office is today, when yesterday everyone was either being fired or threatening to quit. Jane: After a storm comes a calm.

dictionary.phrase: After the storm comes a calm.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Things are often calm after an upheaval.  Jill: I can’t believe how peaceful the office is today, when yesterday everyone was either being fired or threatening to quit. Jane: After a storm comes a calm.

dictionary.phrase: after the fashion of someone or something
dictionary.definition: in the manner or style of someone or something.  She walks down the street after the fashion of a grand lady.  The parish church was built after the style of a French cathedral.

dictionary.phrase: after the style of someone or something
dictionary.definition: in the manner or style of someone or something.  She walks down the street after the fashion of a grand lady.  The parish church was built after the style of a French cathedral.
to strive toward a particular goal; to direct oneself or one’s energies toward something. You should aim for success. Aim at getting this done on time.
to strive toward a particular goal; to direct oneself or one’s energies toward something. You should aim for success. Aim at getting this done on time.
Aspire to something!; Set one’s goals high! _ Aim for the stars, son! Don’t settle for second best.  Set your sights high. Reach for the stars!
Aspire to something!; Set one’s goals high! _ Aim for the stars, son! Don’t settle for second best.  Set your sights high. Reach for the stars!

dictionary.phrase: ain’t got a grain of sense
dictionary.definition: Rur. is or are foolish.  Mary spends money like there’s no tomorrow. She sure ain’t got a grain of sense.  I wouldn’t trust Jim to take care of my kids. He ain’t got a lick of sense.

dictionary.phrase: ain’t got a lick of sense
dictionary.definition: Rur. is or are foolish.  Mary spends money like there’s no tomorrow. She sure ain’t got a grain of sense.  I wouldn’t trust Jim to take care of my kids. He ain’t got a lick of sense.

dictionary.phrase: ain’t got the brains God gave a squirrel
dictionary.definition: Rur. is or are very foolish.  There goes John, running around barefooted in the snow. He ain’t got the brains God gave a squirrel.  No use trying to explain anything to Jane. She ain’t got the sense God gave geese.

dictionary.phrase: ain’t got the sense God gave geese
dictionary.definition: Rur. is or are very foolish.  There goes John, running around barefooted in the snow. He ain’t got the brains God gave a squirrel.  No use trying to explain anything to Jane. She ain’t got the sense God gave geese.

dictionary.phrase: air one’s dirty linen in public
dictionary.definition: to discuss private or embarrassing matters in public, especially when quarreling. (This linen refers to sheets and tablecloths or other soiled cloth.) _ They are arguing again. Why must they always air their dirty linen in public? _ She will talk to anyone about her problems. Why does she wash her dirty linen in public?

dictionary.phrase: wash one’s dirty linen in public
dictionary.definition: to discuss private or embarrassing matters in public, especially when quarreling. (This linen refers to sheets and tablecloths or other soiled cloth.) _ They are arguing again. Why must they always air their dirty linen in public? _ She will talk to anyone about her problems. Why does she wash her dirty linen in public?
well and healthy.  Jane: How is Bill since his illness last month? Mary: Oh; he’s alive and kicking. The last time I saw Tom, he was alive and well.
well and healthy.  Jane: How is Bill since his illness last month? Mary: Oh; he’s alive and kicking. The last time I saw Tom, he was alive and well.

dictionary.phrase: all dressed up and nowhere to go
dictionary.definition: completely ready for something that has been postponed or has failed to materialize. (May be literal or figurative.) _Tom: I just heard that your company is closed today. Fred: Gee, I’m all dressed up and nowhere to go.  The space shot was cancelled, so all the astronauts are all dressed up with nowhere to go.

dictionary.phrase: all dressed up with nowhere to go
dictionary.definition: completely ready for something that has been postponed or has failed to materialize. (May be literal or figurative.) _Tom: I just heard that your company is closed today. Fred: Gee, I’m all dressed up and nowhere to go.  The space shot was cancelled, so all the astronauts are all dressed up with nowhere to go.

being serious for a moment; in all seriousness.  I know I laugh at him but, joking aside, he’s a very clever scientist.  I know I threatened to leave and go round the world, but, joking aside, I do need a vacation.

being serious for a moment; in all seriousness.  I know I laugh at him but, joking aside, he’s a very clever scientist.  I know I threatened to leave and go round the world, but, joking aside, I do need a vacation.

Rur. in good health; feeling good. (*Also: as ~.) _Tom: How are you today? Bill: All oak and iron bound, thank you.  Jane made a wonderful recovery from her surgery, and now she’s as sound as a barrel.

Rur. everywhere.  Little Billy had his toys spread out all over creation. It took forever to clean up after him.  They’re looking all over creation, trying to find the missing man.  Tom has traveled all over hell and half of Georgia trying to find the man who done him wrong.

dictionary.phrase: all over hell and half of Georgia

everywhere. Gravity acts the same all over the earth. Human nature is the same all over the world.
everywhere. Gravity acts the same all over the earth. Human nature is the same all over the world.

dictionary.phrase: All that glitters is not gold.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Just because something looks attractive does not mean it is genuine or valuable. (Often said as a warning.) _ Hollywood may look like an exciting place to live, but I don’t think you should move there. All that glitters is not gold.  I know Susie is popular and pretty, but don’t be fooled by that. All that glitters is not gold.

dictionary.phrase: All that glistens is not gold.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Just because something looks attractive does not mean it is genuine or valuable. (Often said as a warning.) _ Hollywood may look like an exciting place to live, but I don’t think you should move there. All that glitters is not gold.  I know Susie is popular and pretty, but don’t be fooled by that. All that glitters is not gold.

dictionary.phrase: all the more reason for doing something
dictionary.definition: with even better reason or cause for doing something. (Can be included in a number of grammatical constructions.) _ Bill: I don’t do well in calculus because I don’t like the stuff. Father: All the more reason for working harder at it.  Bob: I’m tired of painting this fence. It’s so old it’s rotting! Sally: All the more reason to paint it.

dictionary.phrase: all the more reason to do something
dictionary.definition: with even better reason or cause for doing something. (Can be included in a number of grammatical constructions.) _ Bill: I don’t do well in calculus because I don’t like the stuff. Father: All the more reason for working harder at it.  Bob: I’m tired of painting this fence. It’s so old it’s rotting! Sally: All the more reason to paint it.
nevertheless; anyhow.  They were told not to bring presents, but they brought them all the same.  His parents told him to stay home, but John went out just the same.
nevertheless; anyhow.  They were told not to bring presents, but they brought them all the same.  His parents told him to stay home, but John went out just the same.

of no consequence to someone—one way or the other; [of a choice] immaterial to someone.  It’s all the same to me whether we win or lose.  If it’s just the same to you, I’d rather walk than ride.  If it’s all the same, I’d rather you didn’t smoke.

Everything comes to an end eventually.  You’ll get over this setback. All things must pass.
Everything comes to an end eventually.  You’ll get over this setback. All things must pass.

[for someone or something] liked or used by all people; [for someone or something] everything that is wanted by all people.  You simply can’t be all things to all people. The candidate set out to be all things to all men and came off looking very wishy-washy.

dictionary.phrase: allocate something to someone or something
dictionary.definition: to give or assign something to someone or something. (Between with two, among with three or more.) _The committee allocated the surplus cheese to the elderly people in the community.  David allocated the money among all the members.  He allocated the work between Fred and George.  We had to allocate the money between the philanthropy and social committees.

dictionary.phrase: allocate something between someone or something
dictionary.definition: to give or assign something to someone or something. (Between with two, among with three or more.) _The committee allocated the surplus cheese to the elderly people in the community.  David allocated the money among all the members.  He allocated the work between Fred and George.  We had to allocate the money between the philanthropy and social committees.

dictionary.phrase: allocate something among someone or something
dictionary.definition: to give or assign something to someone or something. (Between with two, among with three or more.) _The committee allocated the surplus cheese to the elderly people in the community.  David allocated the money among all the members.  He allocated the work between Fred and George.  We had to allocate the money between the philanthropy and social committees.

Please let me help you. (Typically said by someone politely assisting another person, as by opening a door or providing some personal service. In Allow me, the stress is usually on me. In Permit me, the stress is usually on -mit.) _ Tom and Jane approached the door. “Allow me,” said Tom, grabbing the doorknob.  “Permit me,” said Fred, pulling out a gold-plated lighter and lighting Jane’s cigarette.

Please let me help you. (Typically said by someone politely assisting another person, as by opening a door or providing some personal service. In Allow me, the stress is usually on me. In Permit me, the stress is usually on -mit.) _ Tom and Jane approached the door. “Allow me,” said Tom, grabbing the doorknob.  “Permit me,” said Fred, pulling out a gold-plated lighter and lighting Jane’s cigarette.

dictionary.phrase: allow someone or something into a place
dictionary.definition: to permit someone or something to enter some place.  Will they allow you in the restaurant without a tie? _ They won’t allow in too many visitors.
to permit someone or something to enter some place.  Will they allow you in the restaurant without a tie? _ They won’t allow in too many visitors.
to react strongly to shock or surprise. Oh! You really scared me. I nearly jumped out of my skin.  Bill was so startled he almost jumped out of his skin.

dictionary.phrase: nearly jump out of one’s skin
dictionary.definition: to react strongly to shock or surprise. Oh! You really scared me. I nearly jumped out of my skin.  Bill was so startled he almost jumped out of his skin.
similarly; in nearly the same way.  We will deal with the other students along similar lines.
similarly; in nearly the same way.  We will deal with the other students along similar lines.
similarly; in nearly the same way.  We will deal with the other students along similar lines.

dictionary.phrase: alternate between someone and someone else
dictionary.definition: to choose or change between two persons or things alternately.  The job will alternate between Gil and Ed. The maid will alternate between the first f loor and the second f loor.

dictionary.phrase: alternate between something and something else
dictionary.definition: to choose or change between two persons or things alternately.  The job will alternate between Gil and Ed. The maid will alternate between the first f loor and the second f loor.

to be the same [as something].  Borrowing can be the same as stealing. If the owner does not know what you have borrowed, it amounts to the same thing.  With cars—whether they’re red or blue—it comes to the same thing.

dictionary.phrase: add up to the same thing
dictionary.definition: to be the same [as something].  Borrowing can be the same as stealing. If the owner does not know what you have borrowed, it amounts to the same thing.  With cars—whether they’re red or blue—it comes to the same thing.

with additional related or similar things mentioned (but not specified).  She told me everything about her kids and so forth.  I heard about problems at work and so forth.  He told me about all his health problems, including his arthritis and so on. I need some help getting ready for dinner, setting the table, and so on.

He told me about all his health problems, including his arthritis and so on. I need some help getting ready for dinner, setting the table, and so on.
with extra left over; with more than is needed. I had as much flour as I needed with some to spare.  Fred said he should have enough cash to last the week—with money to spare.
with extra left over; with more than is needed. I had as much flour as I needed with some to spare.  Fred said he should have enough cash to last the week—with money to spare.
another person to examine something closely in addition to anyone previously.  As soon as we can get a fresh pair of eyes on this mansuscipt, we will find the last of the typos.
another person to examine something closely in addition to anyone previously.  As soon as we can get a fresh pair of eyes on this mansuscipt, we will find the last of the typos.

to talk back (to someone); to argue (with someone). (Fixed phrase.) _ I wish you wouldn’t answer back to me that way. Please don’t answer me back like that! _Don’t answer back or I’ll ground you for a week!

to fit or suit someone’s aim or goal.  This piece of wood will answer my purpose quite nicely.  The new car serves our purpose perfectly.
to fit or suit someone’s aim or goal.  This piece of wood will answer my purpose quite nicely.  The new car serves our purpose perfectly.
a coy way of asking who?_Sally: Where were you last night? Jane: I had a date. Sally: Anyone I know? _ Bill: I’ve got a date for the formal next month. Henry: Anybody I know?

a phrase indicating that the speaker is waiting for the person spoken to to make the appropriate move or action.  Mary: I think it’s about time to go. Bill: Anytime you’re ready. Surgeon: Shall we begin the operation? Nurse: Anytime you’re ready, Doctor.

a phrase indicating that the speaker is waiting for the person spoken to to make the appropriate move or action.  Mary: I think it’s about time to go. Bill: Anytime you’re ready. Surgeon: Shall we begin the operation? Nurse: Anytime you’re ready, Doctor.

1. How are you? _ Mary: Doing okay? Bill: You bet! How are you? _Bill: Hey, man! Are you doing okay? Tom: Sure thing! And you? 2. How are you surviving this situation or ordeal? _ Mary: You doing okay? Bill: Sure. What about you? Mary: I’m doing fine.  Tom: Wow, that was some turbulence we just hit! Are you doing okay? Mary: I’m still a little frightened, but I’ll make it.

1. How are you? _ Mary: Doing okay? Bill: You bet! How are you? _Bill: Hey, man! Are you doing okay? Tom: Sure thing! And you? 2. How are you surviving this situation or ordeal? _ Mary: You doing okay? Bill: Sure. What about you? Mary: I’m doing fine.  Tom: Wow, that was some turbulence we just hit! Are you doing okay? Mary: I’m still a little frightened, but I’ll make it.

a polite inquiry made to a guest who has announced a departure. (Appropriate only for the first few guests to leave. It would seem sarcastic to say this to the last guest to leave or one who is leaving very late at night.) _ Sue: We really must go. Sally: Leaving so soon? Sue: Fred has to catch a plane at five in the morning.  John (seeing Tom at the door): You leaving so soon? Tom: Yes, thanks for inviting me. I really have to go. John: Well, good night, then.

a polite inquiry made to a guest who has announced a departure. (Appropriate only for the first few guests to leave. It would seem sarcastic to say this to the last guest to leave or one who is leaving very late at night.) _ Sue: We really must go. Sally: Leaving so soon? Sue: Fred has to catch a plane at five in the morning.  John (seeing Tom at the door): You leaving so soon? Tom: Yes, thanks for inviting me. I really have to go. John: Well, good night, then.

dictionary.phrase: argue one’s way out of something
dictionary.definition: to talk and get oneself free of a problem.  You can’t argue your way out of this! _It’s a problem, and there is no way that you can argue your way out.
to talk and get oneself free of a problem.  You can’t argue your way out of this! _It’s a problem, and there is no way that you can argue your way out.

dictionary.phrase: arguing for the sake of arguing
dictionary.definition: arguing simply to be difficult or contrary. You are just arguing for the sake of arguing. You don’t even know what the issue is. He is annoying, because he is always arguing for the sake of argument.

dictionary.phrase: arguing for the sake of argument
dictionary.definition: arguing simply to be difficult or contrary. You are just arguing for the sake of arguing. You don’t even know what the issue is. He is annoying, because he is always arguing for the sake of argument.
to get up from something. What time did you arise from bed? _ I arose out of my slumbers at dawn.
to get up from something. What time did you arise from bed? _ I arose out of my slumbers at dawn.
to make a decision; decide.  Have you arrived at a decision yet? _ We will reach a decision tomorrow.
to make a decision; decide.  Have you arrived at a decision yet? _ We will reach a decision tomorrow.

dictionary.phrase: arrive (somewhere) (up)on the stroke of some time
dictionary.definition: to reach a place at a particular instant of time. (Upon is more formal and less commonly used than on.) _She arrived home on the stroke of midnight. We all arrived at the stroke of two.

dictionary.phrase: arrive (somewhere) at the stroke of some time
dictionary.definition: to reach a place at a particular instant of time. (Upon is more formal and less commonly used than on.) _She arrived home on the stroke of midnight. We all arrived at the stroke of two.

to reach the location of an event in progress. (Upon is formal and less commonly used than on and at.) _ The police arrived on the scene of the crime.  They arrived upon the scene of a frightening accident.  What did they do when they arrived at the scene?

to reach the location of an event in progress. (Upon is formal and less commonly used than on and at.) _ The police arrived on the scene of the crime.  They arrived upon the scene of a frightening accident.  What did they do when they arrived at the scene?

to the limits of anyone’s knowledge. (The anyone can be replaced with a more specific noun or pronoun.) _As far as anyone knows, this is the last of the great herds of buffalo. Far as I know, this is the best spot to sit.  Q: Are the trains on time? A: To the best of my knowledge, all the trains are on time today.

Far as I know, this is the best spot to sit.  Q: Are the trains on time? A: To the best of my knowledge, all the trains are on time today.

dictionary.phrase: to the best of one’s knowledge
dictionary.definition: to the limits of anyone’s knowledge. (The anyone can be replaced with a more specific noun or pronoun.) _As far as anyone knows, this is the last of the great herds of buffalo. Far as I know, this is the best spot to sit.  Q: Are the trains on time? A: To the best of my knowledge, all the trains are on time today.

as much as possible; to whatever degree is possible.  We must try, as far as possible, to get people to stop smoking in buses.  As far as possible, the police will issue tickets to all speeding drivers.  I’ll follow your instructions so far as possible.

as much as possible; to whatever degree is possible.  We must try, as far as possible, to get people to stop smoking in buses.  As far as possible, the police will issue tickets to all speeding drivers.  I’ll follow your instructions so far as possible.

dictionary.phrase: as far as someone is concerned
dictionary.definition: from the point of view of someone.  Bob: Isn’t this cake good? Alice: Yes, indeed. This is the best cake I have ever eaten as far as I’m concerned.  As far as we are concerned, anything at all would be fine for dinner.

dictionary.phrase: so far as someone is concerned
dictionary.definition: from the point of view of someone.  Bob: Isn’t this cake good? Alice: Yes, indeed. This is the best cake I have ever eaten as far as I’m concerned.  As far as we are concerned, anything at all would be fine for dinner.

dictionary.phrase: as far as something is concerned
dictionary.definition: having to do with something; pertaining to something; as for something.  This bill? As far as that’s concerned, the committee will have to take care of it. As far as the roof ’s concerned, it will just have to last another year.

dictionary.phrase: so far as something is concerned
dictionary.definition: having to do with something; pertaining to something; as for something.  This bill? As far as that’s concerned, the committee will have to take care of it. As far as the roof ’s concerned, it will just have to last another year.

the way I think about it.  Tom: This matter is not as bad as some would make it out to be. Alice: Yes. This whole affair has been overblown, as I see it.  Bob: You’re as wrong as can be. John: In my view, you are wrong.

the way I think about it.  Tom: This matter is not as bad as some would make it out to be. Alice: Yes. This whole affair has been overblown, as I see it.  Bob: You’re as wrong as can be. John: In my view, you are wrong.

to repeat what I’ve been saying; to continue with what I was saying. (The first form is appropriate in any conversation. The second form is colloquial, informal, and familiar. In addition, this use of like for as, in the second form, is objected to by many people.) _ Bill: Now, Mary, this is one of the round ones that attaches to the wire here. Bob (passing through the room): Hello, you two! I’ll talk to you later. Bill: Yeah, see you around. Now, as I was saying, Mary, this goes here on this wire.  Tom: I hate to interrupt, but someone’s car is being broken into down on the street. Fred: As I was saying, these illegal practices must stop.

to repeat what I’ve been saying; to continue with what I was saying. (The first form is appropriate in any conversation. The second form is colloquial, informal, and familiar. In addition, this use of like for as, in the second form, is objected to by many people.) _ Bill: Now, Mary, this is one of the round ones that attaches to the wire here. Bob (passing through the room): Hello, you two! I’ll talk to you later. Bill: Yeah, see you around. Now, as I was saying, Mary, this goes here on this wire.  Tom: I hate to interrupt, but someone’s car is being broken into down on the street. Fred: As I was saying, these illegal practices must stop.

Cliché just now; at this very moment.  “I’m sorry, sir,” consoled the agent at the gate, “the plane is taking off as we speak.” _ Tom: Waiter, where is my steak? It’s taking a long time. Waiter: It is being grilled even as we speak, sir—just as you requested.

Cliché just now; at this very moment.  “I’m sorry, sir,” consoled the agent at the gate, “the plane is taking off as we speak.” _ Tom: Waiter, where is my steak? It’s taking a long time. Waiter: It is being grilled even as we speak, sir—just as you requested.

dictionary.phrase: As you make your bed, so you must lie (up)on it.
dictionary.definition: Prov. You have to suffer the consequences of what you do. (Often used as a rebuke.) _ Tom insisted on taking a trip to Florida in August, after we all told him how hot it was then. Now that he’s there, all he does is complain about the heat. As you make your bed, so you must lie upon it.  You were the one who chose these house painters because they were cheap. I told you they’d do a terrible job. As you make your bed, so must you lie in it.

dictionary.phrase: As you make your bed, so you must lie in it.
dictionary.definition: Prov. You have to suffer the consequences of what you do. (Often used as a rebuke.) _ Tom insisted on taking a trip to Florida in August, after we all told him how hot it was then. Now that he’s there, all he does is complain about the heat. As you make your bed, so you must lie upon it.  You were the one who chose these house painters because they were cheap. I told you they’d do a terrible job. As you make your bed, so must you lie in it.

dictionary.phrase: As you sow, so shall you reap.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Things will happen to you good or bad, according to how you behave. (Biblical.) _ You should stop being so cruel to other people. As you sow, so shall you reap.  Fred built an immense fortune by swindling others, but lost it all when someone swindled him. As a man sows, so shall he reap.

dictionary.phrase: As a man sows, so shall he reap.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Things will happen to you good or bad, according to how you behave. (Biblical.) _ You should stop being so cruel to other people. As you sow, so shall you reap.  Fred built an immense fortune by swindling others, but lost it all when someone swindled him. As a man sows, so shall he reap.

to request information (about someone or something) from a number of different sources.  I don’t know the answer. I’ll ask around about it.  Ask about, will you? Find out what people are thinking.  Please ask around about her.

to request information (about someone or something) from a number of different sources.  I don’t know the answer. I’ll ask around about it.  Ask about, will you? Find out what people are thinking.  Please ask around about her.

to seem to be trying to get into trouble; to do something that would cause trouble; to do or say something that will cause trouble.  Stop talking to me that way, John. You’re just asking for trouble. The guard asked me to leave unless I was looking for trouble.

to seem to be trying to get into trouble; to do something that would cause trouble; to do or say something that will cause trouble.  Stop talking to me that way, John. You’re just asking for trouble. The guard asked me to leave unless I was looking for trouble.

dictionary.phrase: Ask no questions and hear no lies.
dictionary.definition: If you ask me that, my answer might not be the truth. (Implies that you will likely tell a lie, because you do not want to tell the truth.) _ What am I going to give you for your birthday? Ask no questions and hear no lies. Maybe I like Greg, and maybe I don’t. Ask me no questions, I’ll tell you no lies.

dictionary.phrase: Ask me no questions, I’ll tell you no lies.
dictionary.definition: If you ask me that, my answer might not be the truth. (Implies that you will likely tell a lie, because you do not want to tell the truth.) _ What am I going to give you for your birthday? Ask no questions and hear no lies. Maybe I like Greg, and maybe I don’t. Ask me no questions, I’ll tell you no lies.
to invite someone inside some place.  We asked them into the house.  We stopped our friends in the hallway and asked them in.
to invite someone inside some place.  We asked them into the house.  We stopped our friends in the hallway and asked them in.
rapidly. (*Typically: go ~; move ~; run ~; travel ~.) _ We were moving along at a good clip when a state trooper stopped us.
rapidly. (*Typically: go ~; move ~; run ~; travel ~.) _ We were moving along at a good clip when a state trooper stopped us.
with very little advance notice; with just a little bit of warning.  They are always asking us to produce reports at a moment’s notice.
with very little advance notice; with just a little bit of warning.  They are always asking us to produce reports at a moment’s notice.
very slowly.  Things are moving along at a snail’s pace here, but we’ll finish on time—have no fear.  Poor old Wally is creeping at a snail’s gallop because his car has a f lat tire.
very slowly.  Things are moving along at a snail’s pace here, but we’ll finish on time—have no fear.  Poor old Wally is creeping at a snail’s gallop because his car has a f lat tire.
regardless of the difficulty or cost; no matter what.  I intend to have that car at all costs.  Mary was going to get that job at any cost.
regardless of the difficulty or cost; no matter what.  I intend to have that car at all costs.  Mary was going to get that job at any cost.

in the most favorable view; in the most positive judgment; as the best one can say. At best we found their visit pleasantly short.  The dinner was not at all pleasant. At best the food was not burned.  At most there were three people in line ahead of me.

in the most favorable view; in the most positive judgment; as the best one can say. At best we found their visit pleasantly short.  The dinner was not at all pleasant. At best the food was not burned.  At most there were three people in line ahead of me.

when first examined; at an early stage.  At first glance, the problem appeared quite simple. Later we learned just how complex it really was. He appeared quite healthy at first glance. At first blush, she appeared to be quite old.

when first examined; at an early stage.  At first glance, the problem appeared quite simple. Later we learned just how complex it really was. He appeared quite healthy at first glance. At first blush, she appeared to be quite old.
as fast as possible.  The motor was running at full speed.  John finished his running at full tilt.  When the horse reached the back stretch he was at full throttle.
as fast as possible.  The motor was running at full speed.  John finished his running at full tilt.  When the horse reached the back stretch he was at full throttle.
as fast as possible.  The motor was running at full speed.  John finished his running at full tilt.  When the horse reached the back stretch he was at full throttle.
[of a flag] halfway up or down its flagpole.  The f lag was f lying at half-mast because the general had died. Americans f ly f lags at halfstaff on Memorial Day.
[of a flag] halfway up or down its flagpole.  The f lag was f lying at half-mast because the general had died. Americans f ly f lags at halfstaff on Memorial Day.
at one’s convenience.  Choose one or the other at your leisure.  Please drop by at your leisure.
at one’s convenience.  Choose one or the other at your leisure.  Please drop by at your leisure.

in conflict with someone; having reached an impasse (about something).  Tom is at loggerheads with Bill. We are at loggerheads with each other.  The twins were at loggerheads over who should take the larger room.

in conflict with someone; having reached an impasse (about something).  Tom is at loggerheads with Bill. We are at loggerheads with each other.  The twins were at loggerheads over who should take the larger room.
in opposition to someone; at loggerheads (with someone). Mary is always at odds with her father about how late she can stay out.  John and his father are always at odds over what to watch on TV.
in opposition to someone; at loggerheads (with someone). Mary is always at odds with her father about how late she can stay out.  John and his father are always at odds over what to watch on TV.

in a single incident; as a single event. (This phrase preserves the old word fell, meaning “terrible” or “deadly.”) _The party guests ate up all the snacks at one fell swoop.  When the stock market crashed, many large fortunes were wiped out in one fell swoop.

in a single incident; as a single event. (This phrase preserves the old word fell, meaning “terrible” or “deadly.”) _The party guests ate up all the snacks at one fell swoop.  When the stock market crashed, many large fortunes were wiped out in one fell swoop.

in someone’s care; as someone’s responsibility.  Why do you always have to lay your problems at my doorstep? _ I shall put this issue on someone else’s doorstep. I don’t want that problem on my doorstep.

in someone’s care; as someone’s responsibility.  Why do you always have to lay your problems at my doorstep? _ I shall put this issue on someone else’s doorstep. I don’t want that problem on my doorstep.

dictionary.phrase: at the bottom of the ladder
dictionary.definition: at the lowest level of pay and status. (Alludes to the lowness of the bottom rung of a ladder.) _Most people start work at the bottom of the ladder.  After Ann got fired, she had to start all over again on the bottom rung.

dictionary.phrase: on the bottom rung (of the ladder)
dictionary.definition: at the lowest level of pay and status. (Alludes to the lowness of the bottom rung of a ladder.) _Most people start work at the bottom of the ladder.  After Ann got fired, she had to start all over again on the bottom rung.
at the earliest light of the day. Jane was always awake at the crack of dawn.  The birds start singing at the break of dawn.
at the earliest light of the day. Jane was always awake at the crack of dawn.  The birds start singing at the break of dawn.

dictionary.phrase: at the end of one’s rope
dictionary.definition: at the limits of one’s endurance.  I’m at the end of my rope! I just can’t go on this way! _ These kids are driving me out of my mind. I’m at the end of my tether.

dictionary.phrase: at the end of one’s tether
dictionary.definition: at the limits of one’s endurance.  I’m at the end of my rope! I just can’t go on this way! _ These kids are driving me out of my mind. I’m at the end of my tether.

at the place of greatest activity; vital or important to some activity.  I interviewed Max Brown, the director who is in the forefront of the movie industry. The university I go to is at the forefront of computer technology.

at the place of greatest activity; vital or important to some activity.  I interviewed Max Brown, the director who is in the forefront of the movie industry. The university I go to is at the forefront of computer technology.
under the control of someone; without defense against someone. We were left at the mercy of the arresting officer.  Mrs. Franklin wanted Mr. Franklin at her mercy.
under the control of someone; without defense against someone. We were left at the mercy of the arresting officer.  Mrs. Franklin wanted Mr. Franklin at her mercy.
Cliché now; at present. (Used often as a wordy replacement for now.) _We don’t know the location of the stolen car at the present time.  The patient is doing nicely at the present time.
Cliché now; at present. (Used often as a wordy replacement for now.) _We don’t know the location of the stolen car at the present time.  The patient is doing nicely at the present time.

dictionary.phrase: at the top of one’s voice
dictionary.definition: very loudly. Bill called to Mary at the top of his voice.  How can I drive safely when you’re all screaming at the top of your lungs?

dictionary.phrase: at the top of one’s lungs
dictionary.definition: very loudly. Bill called to Mary at the top of his voice.  How can I drive safely when you’re all screaming at the top of your lungs?

dictionary.phrase: avenge oneself (on someone or something) (for something)
dictionary.definition: to get even with, or take revenge against someone or something for some hurt or damage.  They avenged themselves on the enemy for the surprise attack.  He avenged himself against the storekeeper for the false charges.  Mary avenged herself for her ex-husband’s neglect to pay child support. Tom avenged himself on Bill for Bill’s previous insults.

dictionary.phrase: avenge oneself (against someone or something) (for something)
dictionary.definition: to get even with, or take revenge against someone or something for some hurt or damage.  They avenged themselves on the enemy for the surprise attack.  He avenged himself against the storekeeper for the false charges.  Mary avenged herself for her ex-husband’s neglect to pay child support. Tom avenged himself on Bill for Bill’s previous insults.

to equal something as the average of a set of figures.  The figures averaged out at what was expected.  Will the charges average out to a reasonable figure? _Over time, our expenses will average out to a low monthly outlay.

to equal something as the average of a set of figures.  The figures averaged out at what was expected.  Will the charges average out to a reasonable figure? _Over time, our expenses will average out to a low monthly outlay.
to give a prize or reward to someone (for something).  The committee awarded a plaque to Andy for his loyalty.  They awarded prizes for efficiency to two different people.
to give a prize or reward to someone (for something).  The committee awarded a plaque to Andy for his loyalty.  They awarded prizes for efficiency to two different people.

dictionary.phrase: *awkward as a cow on a crutch
dictionary.definition: very clumsy or off balance. (*Also: as ~.) _When Lulu was overweight, she was awkward as a cow on a crutch.  Tom will never be a gymnast. He’s as awkward as a cow on roller skates!

dictionary.phrase: *awkward as a cow on roller skates
dictionary.definition: very clumsy or off balance. (*Also: as ~.) _When Lulu was overweight, she was awkward as a cow on a crutch.  Tom will never be a gymnast. He’s as awkward as a cow on roller skates!

1. to attend and care for a child for a period of time. I’m looking for someone to babysit for my cousin. Will you babysit with my cousin? 2. to attend and care for a child for someone for a short period of time.  Would you mind babysitting Roger for me for a few minutes? _ Sure, I will babysit for you.

1. to attend and care for a child for a period of time. I’m looking for someone to babysit for my cousin. Will you babysit with my cousin? 2. to attend and care for a child for someone for a short period of time.  Would you mind babysitting Roger for me for a few minutes? _ Sure, I will babysit for you.
to move backwards from a person or thing; to withdraw physically from someone or something.  You should back away from the fire. Please back off from the man who is threatening you.
to move backwards from a person or thing; to withdraw physically from someone or something.  You should back away from the fire. Please back off from the man who is threatening you.

dictionary.phrase: back someone or something out of something
dictionary.definition: to guide or move someone or something backwards out of something or some place.  Judy backed the car out of the garage. Please back out the car.  Don backed Fred out of the garage.
to guide or move someone or something backwards out of something or some place.  Judy backed the car out of the garage. Please back out the car.  Don backed Fred out of the garage.

dictionary.phrase: back someone or something up to someone or something
dictionary.definition: to guide or move someone or something backwards to someone or something.  She backed the car up to the end of the street.  Using hand signals, Todd helped back Mary up to the gas pump.  He backed up the motor home carefully.

to guide or move someone or something backwards to someone or something.  She backed the car up to the end of the street.  Using hand signals, Todd helped back Mary up to the gas pump.  He backed up the motor home carefully.
an unintended or ambiguous compliment. Backhanded compliments are the only kind he ever gives! _And I think his left-handed compliments are all given by accident, too!
an unintended or ambiguous compliment. Backhanded compliments are the only kind he ever gives! _And I think his left-handed compliments are all given by accident, too!
a period that offers difficulties, such as when there is not enough food, money, or work.  We went through trying times when Perry was out of work, but we all bounced back.

with one’s luggage; with all one’s possessions.  Sally showed up at our door bag and baggage one Sunday morning.  All right, if you won’t pay the rent, out with you, bag and baggage! _ Get all your stuff—part and parcel—out of here!

Sl. Be quiet!; Shut up and go away! _ Mary: Sally, you look just terrible! What happened? Sally: Bag it! Mary: Sorry I asked! _Bill: Did I ever tell you about the time I went to Germany? Sue: Give it a rest, Bill. Bag it! _Sue: Can I borrow your car again? Mary: Bag your face, Sue! Sue: Well, I never!

to deposit a sum of money that allows someone to get out of jail while waiting for a trial. John was in jail. I had to go down to the police station to bail him out.  I need some cash to bail out a friend!

completely bald. (*Also: as ~.) _ If Tom’s hair keeps receding like that, he’ll be bald as a coot by the time he’s thirty.  Fred: Now, I’ll admit my hair is thinning a little on the top, but— Jane: Thinning? You’re not thinning, you’re as bald as a baby’s backside!

an energetic and ambitious person; a go-getter.  That guy is a real ball of fire when it comes to sales.  I don’t want to hire some young fireball. I need wisdom and thoughtfulness.

to plan for something; to expect something. We knew the project would be difficult, but we didn’t bargain for this kind of trouble.  I bargained on an easier time of it than this.

to negotiate with someone about obtaining someone or something.  I refuse to bargain over money with Dan.  We will bargain with the supplier over prices.  You can’t bargain over Claire with Jeff as if she were a car!

to negotiate with someone about obtaining someone or something.  I refuse to bargain over money with Dan.  We will bargain with the supplier over prices.  You can’t bargain over Claire with Jeff as if she were a car!

to say something harshly to someone.  The sergeant barked the orders out at the recruits.  He barked an order at his staff.  The teacher barked a reprimand out to the class. He barked out the order clearly and loudly.

to trade [something] for something else; to acquire something by exchanging goods or services, not by using money.  I want to barter for a large amount of cloth. Will you barter for this month’s rent? _ We will not barter over what you owe us.

to be someone who is not controlled by other people; to be an independent person.  Bert longed to be his own master, but at the same time feared losing the security he had as the employee of a large company.  When I go away to college, I’ll be my own man. My parents won’t be able to tell me what to do anymore.

dictionary.phrase: be so bold as to do something
dictionary.definition: to dare to do something.  Would you care to dance, if I may make so bold as to ask? _She was so bold to confront her rival.

dictionary.phrase: make so bold as to do something
dictionary.definition: to dare to do something.  Would you care to dance, if I may make so bold as to ask? _She was so bold to confront her rival.

to continue feeling an old resentment for someone; to harbor continual anger for someone.  She bears a grudge against the judge who sentenced her.  I have a grudge against my landlord for not fixing the leaky faucet.

to continue feeling an old resentment for someone; to harbor continual anger for someone.  She bears a grudge against the judge who sentenced her.  I have a grudge against my landlord for not fixing the leaky faucet.

to handle or cope with one’s burden; to endure one’s difficulties. (This is a biblical theme. It is always used figuratively except in the biblical context.) _ It’s a very painful disease, but I’ll bear my cross.  I can’t help you with it. You’ll just have to carry your own cross.

dictionary.phrase: beard the lion in his den
dictionary.definition: Prov. to confront someone on his or her own territory. I spent a week trying to reach Mr. Toynbee by phone, but his secretary always told me he was too busy to talk to me. Today I walked straight into his office and bearded the lion in his den.  If the landlord doesn’t contact us soon, we’ll have to beard him in his den.

Today I walked straight into his office and bearded the lion in his den.  If the landlord doesn’t contact us soon, we’ll have to beard him in his den.
to avoid answering a question; to stall; to waste time.  Stop beating around the bush and answer my question.  Let’s stop beating about the bush and discuss this matter.
